metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Best practice recommendations for point-of-care lung ultrasound in patients with suspected COVID-19 TITLE: Best practice recommendations for point-of-care lung ultrasound in patients with suspected COVID-19 AUTHORS: Best practice recommendations for point-of-care lung ultrasound in patients with suspected 1

abstract.text: 4 5 Background: Lung point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is a critical tool for evaluating patients 6

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION 26 27 Lung point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is an invaluable tool for assessing emergency 28 department (ED) patients with dyspnea (1-3). Lung POCUS demonstrates a higher sensitivity 29 than chest x-ray (CXR) in detecting pulmonary pathologies such as pleural effusion, alveolar 30 consolidation, pneumothorax and interstitial syndrome (3-7). Ultrasound also offers benefits over 31 computed tomography (CT), or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) given its low cost, ease of 32 use, ability to offer real-time data, and lack of radiation exposure. Streamlined protocols aimed at 33 differentiating etiologies of dyspnea using POCUS are widely used in the ED, and often are 34 considered standard of care (8). 35 COVID-19, the clinical illness caused by SARS-CoV-2, evolved into a global pandemic 36 over a few short months (9). COVID-19 exhibits a wide range of clinical presentations from 37 asymptomatic to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (10). Given its value in assessing 38 pulmonary pathology, lung POCUS has evolved as an important strategy to evaluate patients 39 with suspected COVID-19 (11-13). Among many challenges encountered during this global 40 crisis, maintaining the health and safety of health care workers (HCWs) has been critical (14-16). 41

Properties of COVID-19 which put HCWs at risk of nosocomial spread include human-to-human 42 transmission via respiratory droplets (17, 18) , and viral fomites which can survive on surfaces for 43 up to 72 hours (19). Unfortunately, given these properties, the time spent scanning potentially 44 infectious patients and the multi-use nature of ultrasound machines makes POCUS a possible Recognizing the dissonance between the clinical utility of POCUS and the added risk of nosocomial spread, emergency medicine and ultrasound professional organizations have 48 published guidelines outlining safe use of ultrasound in the setting of COVID-19 (12, 20-22). 49
These guidelines however largely focus on equipment disinfection, sterilization, and data-sharing 50 while providing few suggestions on best practice image acquisition or scanning protocols. Here, 51

we discuss the typical findings of lung POCUS in cases of COVID-19 leading us to propose a 52 pathologic changes tend to be particularly amenable to assessment by lung POCUS given their 61 peripheral and peri-pleural location. As is also true for other viral or bacterial pneumonias, 62 sonographic findings of COVID-19 can precede radiographic findings (23,24,27). 63 64

Based on our concern for prolonged exposure during scanning, we propose the following 67 protocol. We recommend positioning the patient sitting upright with the operator and machine 68 positioned behind the patient at all times ( Figure 2A ). This avoids direct exposure of the machine and provider to respiratory droplets produced by a tachypneic patient. Additionally, upright 70 positioning may be more comfortable for many patients in acute respiratory distress facilitating 71 easier access to the posterior lung fields. Awake prone positioning may prevent alveolar 72 collapse, improve oxygenation, and in some cases avoid intubation (29-31) . A comparable 73 positioning approach to scanning can be taken in a prone patient ( Figure 2B ). This positioning 74
gives access to the regions with most prominent imaging findings in COVID-19, and thus 75 represent the highest yield scans (23-26). 76
In an upright or proned patient, using either a linear or curvilinear probe locate the most 77

BIBREF36.title: Using a focused scanning protocol will minimize time spent in patients' rooms thus reducing risk 267 of exposure., This scanning protocol focuses on rapidly and accurately identifying most 268 common sonographic findings in COVID-19 and adhering to recommended device 269 decontamination protocols will reduce risk of nosocomial spread to subsequent patients. linear or curvilinear probe sagittal with probe marker cranially to the patient and slide 297 the probe across the posterior surfaces of the patient as shown by the blue arrows (i.e. 298 lawnmower)

FIGREF0.text: focused 6-zone exam which prioritizes imaging acquisition from lung fields where COVID-19 53 findings are most prevalent. 54 55 Lung POCUS in COVID-19 56 Lung POCUS findings most commonly associated with COVID-19 include B-lines which 57 can be isolated or diffuse, an irregular pleural line, sub-pleural consolidations, and peri-pleural 58 edema (Figure 1) (23,24). Findings are typically bilateral and most prominent in the posterior 59 and lateral lung zones inferiorly (13,23-26). Pleural effusions are rarely seen (27). COVID-19 60

FIGREF1.text: inferior portion of the patient's hemithorax posteriorly by identifying the pleural line adjacent to 78 the diaphragm. The bilateral areas from here to the inferior scapula border are known as zones 79 right posterior (RP) and left posterior (LP) (Figure 3A). With the transducer positioned sagittal 80 and the probe marker cranially slide the probe back and forth across the hemithorax between the 81 posterior axillary line and the paravertebral line up to the mid-scapular border (i.e. lawnmower 82 technique, Figure 3C). Avoid scanning directly over the scapula as it obscures views of lung 83 tissue. Once complete, use the lawnmower technique to evaluate the area between the posterior 84 and anterior axillary lines starting at the most posterior and inferior point of the thorax (Figure 853E-F). We refer to these lung zones as lateral superior and lateral inferior zones on the right and 86 left respectively (Figure 3B-C). This protocol should be repeated on the contralateral hemithorax 87 as COVID-19 most commonly demonstrates bilateral findings. 88 89 DISCUSSION 90 Here we present a rapid protocol for performing lung POCUS on patients with suspected from the posterior and lateral lung fields. This protocol maximizes both clinical utility and 93 provider safety when assessing patients with suspected COVID-19. We argue this focused 94 protocol which minimizes time spent scanning and optimizes provider positioning decreases 95 exposure risk for HCWs. 96 Classically, in a supine patient, a 12-point lung POCUS including 2 anterior field zones, 97 2 lateral field zones, and 2 posterior field zones bilaterally has been used to evaluate dyspneic 98 patients in the ED (8). This approach has also been recommended by some for use in patients 99 with suspected COVID-19 (13). Recently, a novel 14-zone lung scan which in addition to the 12-100 zones above adds 2 zones located adjacent to the bilateral scapulae posteriorly has been 101 described for patients with suspected COVID-19 (27). Althought most findings are found both 102 posteriorly and laterally, no protocols have advocated for a 6-zone protocol. Our protocol not 103 only recommends placing patients sitting up or prone instead of supine, it enables providers to 104 have less scanning time thereby decreasing the risk of sustained exposure. 105 In addition to acquiring images from the posterior and lateral lung fields, existing 106 scanning protocols proposed for use patients with COVID-19 also describe assessing the anterior 107 lung fields for B-lines or subpleural consolidations (13,27). While we acknowledge that findings 108 consistent with COVID-19 can be observed anteriorly, in particular B-lines, we argue that 109 scanning anteriorly is often not needed to obtain clinically useful data. Though appropriate 110 personal protective equipment should offer some reassurance, adding anterior lung fields to 111 scanning protocols in these cases confers additional risk of exposure to the sonographer from 112 being positioned in front of an often tachypneic patient and from remaining in the exam room 113 longer than absolute necessary. Our protocol focuses on image acquisition from the posterior and 114 lateral lung fields where sonographic findings of COVID-19 are most likely to be identified. If lung POCUS using our protocol is negative but the provider still suspects pathology, then 116 scanning anterior lung fields may be necessary for diagnosis. In cases where scanning anterior 117 lung fields is deemed necessary, to minimize exposure we recommend maintaining the proposed 118 positioning with the provider and machine placed behind the patient, and the provider can 119 carefully reach around the patient to scan anterior lung fields bilaterally. 120 In our protocol, patient positioning is key to reducing exposure to possible respiratory 121 droplets. Upright positioning may be more comfortable for many patients in acute respiratory 122 distress facilitating easier access to the posterior lung fields. Further, placing patients in a prone 123 position has shown mortality benefit in cases of severe non-SARS-CoV-2-related ARDS (28). 124 Similarly, awake proning in hypoxemic patients with COVID-19 may improve oxygenation, and 125 in come cases avoid intubation (29-31). Both of these patient positions will optimize the 126 operators ability to scan both the posterior and/or lateral lung fields with less exposure POCUS can offer important data, which can aid in clinical decision-making 131 in cases of COVID-19, there are limitations to this tool. Lung POCUS does require a certain 132 amount of operator experience and training to perform, and in inexperienced hands can lead to 133 misinterpretation. Additionally, evidence correlating POCUS findings with either diagnosis or 134 prognosis of COVID-19 is lacking. Thus, all lung POCUS findings in patients with suspected 135 COVID-19 must be correlated with the clinical picture overall. 136 While the ultimate scope of the COVID-19 pandemic is unclear, taking steps to minimize 140 healthcare-associated spread is key to limiting its trajectory. As a powerful tool for evaluating 141 patients with acute dyspnea, there certainly remains a role for lung POCUS in the current clinical 142 environment. However, given that lung POCUS now confers potential risk to providers and 143 patients in the form of nosocomial disease spread, developing protocols and policies which 144 minimize risk while maximizing clinical utility are paramount. Hyperechoic 274 artifacts originating from the pleural known as B-lines are seen ranging from isolated (A, red 275 arrows) to confluent (B, white arrow). C. Pleural lines are often irregular (red box), and can be 276 observed alongside peri-pleural edema (D. white asterisk). E. Subpleural consolidations (red 277 asterisks) are a hallmark of COVID-19 pneumonia and are often seen in the posterior, Lung POCUS positioning and image acquisition for scanning patients with suspected 283 COVID-19. A. In a patient positioned upright, the operator and machine should be positioned 284 behind the patient to minimize exposure risk. B. Safe positioning can be similarly achieved in Anatomy and scanning technique for lung POCUS in patient with COVID-19. A. 289 Landmarks for scanning include the inferior thorax at the level of the diaphragm (curved line), 290 the spine (solid vertical line), the scapula (triangle), and the posterior axillary line (dotted line). 291 Lung position is outlined in blue. Lung zones to be scanned include the areas under the scapula 292 border known as the right posterior (RP) and left posterior (LP) zones. Laterally, landmarks 293 include the posterior axillary line (dotted line) to the anterior axillary line. Lateral lung zones to 294 be scanned include the right lateral superior (RLs) and right lateral inferior (RLi, B), and on the 295 left include the left lateral superior (LLs), and left lateral inferior (LLi, C).
